We are not actually going to separate ourselves

We are already an island – we can’t move

The northern parts of Greater Manchester voted

perceptions of the economy? The point is,
we need to talk about those things because

if we just ignore them, we will never move

What we need to do is make sure that our voices
are heard in the conversation, not just as

96.97.text:
Brexit evolves but as we reshape British law
because all the things that are currently

104.40.text:
bound up with European legislation are going
to be rewritten. Some of them may stay the

108.45.text:
same, some of them may change drastically.
We don’t know but we still have to remember

that we can be part of shaping the future

up for this gig!

We have got to think about what we can bring

we’ve got to be part of the conversation
and we’re not at the moment. There was a

report published in the last few days by the
House of Lords. It had some great stuff about

165.36.text:
charities in but what is going to happen with

funded or are we actually going to find new
ways to make those things happen? What are

I’ve got a bit of a call for a few people.

199.03.text:
charity sector think through what it can do
about the future. What it can do to make sure

206.51.text:
everybody benefits from the opportunities

211.70.text:
for them or not. Opportunities will be there,

I’ve got a call for the government to remember
the voices of people in local communities

224.29.text:
who often voted for Brexit because they felt
left out. How are we going to keep them included?

How are we going to make all those voices

240.15.text:

I think we’ve got a conversation to have
with ourselves as a charity sector and by

249.20.text:

253.31.text:
got to think about how we can speak more loudly.

265.97.text:
we have to do a lot more. This isn’t a political

And we should do because that is how we shape
the future.

274.88.text:
And we can do that by culture, by conversation,
by debate, by encouraging everyone to feel

282.73.text:
they have a right to be part of this. Maybe
that is the most important thing we can do

286.87.text:
because that is about the productivity of
the country and I don’t just mean productivity

291.49.text:
in the economic sense, I mean productivity
in terms of us all feeling like we are part

303.32.text:

We’ve got to move past that, we’ve got

307.95.text:
to find ways to say we can work together to
make this a success, whatever it is.

315.06.text:
The last thing I’d say is that, in a digital
world that we now live in, many people are

321.51.text:
growing up never knowing any other way. They
expect that you are connected to everyone

328.19.text:
everywhere in the world all the time. And
I think we have to remember that as a huge

334.01.text:
opportunity for the future. Most of us in
the charity sector struggle to get our heads

338.95.text:
around all the digital stuff because it’s
usually something we can’t afford to do

343.20.text:

I think that’s part of the global conversation

347.73.text:
and I do mean global. I mean actually forming
those relationships with people in communities
